concepts.interpretation: Court holds that schemes framed under S.92 CPC can include a reserved power for future modification by application to the court without requiring a fresh suit under S.92, provided it is for administration purposes and does not affect private rights.

concepts.unlisted_description: Provision for suits relating to public charitable/religious trusts, including framing schemes.

anchor.surface_text: Section 92 permits a suit in the case of any alleged breach of any express or constructive trust created for public purposes of a charitable or religious nature or where the direction of the court is deemed necessary for the administration of any such trust to be filed either by the Advocate-General or two or more persons having an interest in the trust with the consent in writing of the Advocate-General. Reliefs that can be obtained under that section are- (a) removing any trustee (b) appointing a new trustee (c) vesting any property in a trustee (cc) directing a trustee who has been removed or a person who has ceased to be trustee, to deliver possession of any trust property in his possession to the person entitled to the possession of such property (d) directing accounts and inquiries (e) declaring what proportion of the trust property or of the interest therein shall be allocated to any particular object of the trust (f) authorising the whole or any part of the trust property to be let, sold, mortgaged or exchanged (g) settling a scheme or (h) granting such further or other relief as the nature of the case may require.

concepts.interpretation: Enumerated reliefs (a)-(h), particularly (g) settling a scheme, allow comprehensive power including reserving modification clause for administrative purposes.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: e and companyvenient that a scheme should companytain a provision for its modification, as that would provide a speedier remedy for modification of th

concepts.unlisted_description: Reliefs available in public trust suits.

anchor.surface_text: Further sub-s. (2) of s. 92 bars a suit claiming the above reliefs unless the suit is filed in conformity with s. 92(1).

concepts.interpretation: Does not bar applications for scheme modification if clause reserved in original scheme; suit ends with decree but scheme can be elastic for administration.

a suit under s. 92 is a representative suit and binds not only the parties thereto but all those who are interested in the trust. anchor.surface_text: It was held in that case that-- if in a decree for a scheme framed under s. 92, Civil Procedure Code, liberty is given to persons to apply to the Court for directions merely to carry out the scheme already settled, such reservation of liberty in the decree will be intra vires if the assistance of the Court can be given without offending s. 92 but where liberty is given to apply to the Court for alteration or modification of the scheme, such reservation is ultra vires as offending s. 92.

issues.text: how far it is open to a court to amend a scheme once framed under s. 92 of the Code of Civil Procedure, where a power to amend the scheme is reserved in the scheme itself

anchor.surface_text: The main question that arises in this appeal is how far it is open to a court to amend a scheme once framed under s. 92 of the Code of Civil Procedure, where a power to amend the scheme is reserved in the scheme itself.

issues.text: whether there is anything in s. 92 of the Code of Civil Procedure which militates against providing a clause in a scheme framed thereunder for its modification by an application to the court framing the scheme

anchor.surface_text: Apart from authorities, however, let us see if there is anything in s. 92 of the Code of Civil Procedure which militates against providing a clause in a scheme framed thereunder for its modification by an application to the court.

issues.text: whether in a case where there is a provision in the scheme for its modification by an application to the court, it is open to the court to make modifications therein without the necessity of a suit under s. 92

anchor.surface_text: We shall confine ourselves only to the question whether in a case where there is a provision in the scheme for its modification by an application to the court, it is open to the court to make modifications therein without the necessity of a suit under s. 92.

precedents.citation: Veeraraghavachariar v. The Advocate-General of Madras 1 ... 1928 I.L.R. 51 Mad. 31.

anchor.surface_text: The leading case in support of the view taken by the High Court is Veeraraghavachariar v. The Advocate-General of Madras  1 . It was held in that case that-- if in a decree for a scheme framed under s. 92, Civil Procedure Code, liberty is given to persons to apply to the Court for directions merely to carry out the scheme already settled, such reservation of liberty in the decree will be intra vires if the assistance of the Court can be given without, offending s. 92 but where liberty is given to apply to the Court for alteration or modification of the scheme, such reservation is ultra vires as offending s. 92.

precedents.case_name: Veeraraghavachariar v. The Advocate-General of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: liberty given to apply to the Court for alteration or modification of the scheme is ultra vires as offending s. 92 CPC
precedents.cited_holding: if in a decree for a scheme framed under s. 92, Civil Procedure Code, liberty is given to persons to apply to the Court for directions merely to carry out the scheme already settled, such reservation of liberty in the decree will be intra vires if the assistance of the Court can be given without offending s. 92 but where liberty is given to apply to the Court for alteration or modification of the scheme, such reservation is ultra vires as offending s. 92.

precedents.citation: Chandraprasad Ramprasad v. Jinabharathi Narayana bharathi 2 ... 1931 I.I.R. 55 Bom. 414

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand the leading case taking the opposite view is Chandraprasad Ramprasad v. Jinabharathi Narayana bharathi  2 . In that case the scheme authorised the District Court to remove a trustee and also to alter or amend the scheme upon an application of a party interested or on its own initiative after giving public notice.

precedents.case_name: Chandraprasad Ramprasad v. Jinabharathi Narayana bharathi
precedents.cited_proposition: District Court competent to grant reliefs like removal of trustees and modification of scheme by virtue of powers conferred under the rules of the scheme without separate suit under s.92 CPC

precedents.citation: Sri Swami Rangacharya v. Gangaram 1 ... 1936 I.L.R. 58 All. 538

anchor.surface_text: The view taken by the Bombay High Court as to the power to modify the scheme by application if such power is reserved in the scheme has been followed by the Allahabad High Court in Sri Swami Rangacharya v. Gangaram  1 .

precedents.cited_proposition: followed the Bombay view that scheme can be modified by application if power reserved

precedents.citation: Umeshananda Dutta Jha v. Sir Ravaneswar Prasad Singh 2 ... 1912 17 C.W. N. 841

anchor.surface_text: The Calcutta High Court has also accepted the view that where there is a provision in a scheme for its modification it can be modified by an application see Umeshananda Dutta Jha v. Sir Ravaneswar Prasad Singh  2

precedents.case_name: Umeshananda Dutta Jha v. Sir Ravaneswar Prasad Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: scheme with provision for modification can be modified by application

precedents.citation: Manadananda Jha v. Tarakananda Jha Panda 3 ... A.I.R. 1924 Cal. 330

anchor.surface_text: Manadananda Jha v. Tarakananda Jha Panda  3   and Srijib Nyayatirtha v. Sreemant Dandy Swami Jagannath Ashram  4  . The Patna High Court also in Mahomed Waheb Hussain v. Syed Abbas Husain  5  held the same view.

precedents.case_name: Manadananda Jha v. Tarakananda Jha Panda
precedents.cited_proposition: scheme with provision for modification can be modified by application

precedents.citation: Srijib Nyayatirtha v. Sreemant Dandy Swami Jagannath Ashram 4 ... A.I.R. 1941 Cal. 618

anchor.surface_text: and Srijib Nyayatirtha v. Sreemant Dandy Swami Jagannath Ashram  4  . The Patna High Court also in Mahomed Waheb Hussain v. Syed Abbas Husain  5  held the same view.

precedents.case_name: Srijib Nyayatirtha v. Sreemant Dandy Swami Jagannath Ashram
precedents.cited_proposition: scheme with provision for modification can be modified by application

precedents.citation: Mahomed Waheb Hussain v. Syed Abbas Husain 5 ... A.I.R. 1923 Pat. 420

anchor.surface_text: The Patna High Court also in Mahomed Waheb Hussain v. Syed Abbas Husain  5  held the same view. In Gangaram Govind Pashankar v. Sardar R. Vinchurkar  6 , the Bombay High Court has gone further and held that the court had inherent power under s. 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure to alter a scheme even in the absence of a clause giving liberty to apply if circumstances have subsequently arisen which make it desirable for it to be altered to meet the ends of justice.

precedents.case_name: Mahomed Waheb Hussain v. Syed Abbas Husain
precedents.cited_proposition: scheme with provision for modification can be modified by application

precedents.citation: Gangaram Govind Pashankar v. Sardar R. Vinchurkar 6 ... I.L.R. 1947 BOM. 466

anchor.surface_text: In Gangaram Govind Pashankar v. Sardar R. Vinchurkar  6 , the Bombay High Court has gone further and held that the court had inherent power under s. 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure to alter a scheme even in the absence of a clause giving liberty to apply if circumstances have subsequently arisen which make it desirable for it to be altered to meet the ends of justice.

precedents.case_name: Gangaram Govind Pashankar v. Sardar R. Vinchurkar
precedents.cited_proposition: court has inherent power under s.151 CPC to alter scheme even without reserved clause if necessary for justice

precedents.citation: Prayaga Doss Jee Varu v. Tirumala Anandam Pillai Purisa Sriranga Charylu Varu 1 ... 1907 L.R. 3 T.A. 78

anchor.surface_text: Reference was also made to two decisions of the Privy Council. In Prayaga Doss Jee Varu v. Tirumala Anandam Pillai Purisa Sriranga Charylu Varu  1 , the Privy Council itself framed a scheme and one of the terms in the scheme was that liberty was reserved to persons interested from time to time to apply to the High Court for any modification of the scheme that may appear to be necessary or convenient.

precedents.case_name: Prayaga Doss Jee Varu v. Tirumala Anandam Pillai Purisa Sriranga Charylu Varu
precedents.cited_proposition: Privy Council framed scheme reserving liberty to apply for modification

precedents.citation: Sevak Kirpashanker Daji v. Copal Rao Manohar Pambekar 2 ... 1913 24 M.L.J 199

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, in Sevak Kirpashanker Daji v. Copal Rao Manohar Pambekar 2  ,the scheme which was framed by the Privy Council in that case contained in cl. 20 a direction that the provisions of the scheme might be altered, modified or added to by an application to His Majestys High Court of Judicature at Bombay.

precedents.case_name: Sevak Kirpashanker Daji v. Copal Rao Manohar Pambekar
precedents.cited_proposition: Privy Council framed scheme containing clause authorising alteration by application to High Court

anchor.surface_text: In Veeraraghavachariars case  1 , the Madras High Court was cognizant of the two decisions of the Privy Council in which clauses had been inserted in the scheme providing for its modification by an application. But the learned judges were of the view that the point was never raised much less decided by the Privy Council and therefore it could not be said that the Privy Council was of the opinion that such a clause would be intra vires.

precedents.case_name: Veeraraghavachariar v. The Advocate-General of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Madras HC aware of PC cases but held point not decided, such clause ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the High Court and restore the revised scheme subject to the modifications suggested by us above.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside; District Judge's revised scheme restored subject to Supreme Court modifications regarding administration, pujaris' duties, control, punishment appeal, and offerings handling.
directions: set aside the order of the High Court
restore the revised scheme subject to the modifications suggested by us above
The District Judge will see that these modifications are embodied in the revised scheme
Clarify addition in paragraph 3: substitute for pujari lacking mantrik ritual knowledge to be provided by the pujari, not trustee

Add to clause b of paragraph 12: 'In case Raje Anandrao or his manager or agent fines or punishes the pujaris for misconduct, the pujaris will have the right to appeal to the District Judge against such orders and the order of the District Judge thereon will be final.'

Amend clause c of paragraph 12 to incorporate detailed order provisions and safeguards: double-locked box for offerings up to Rs. 5/-, opened periodically in presence of representatives and respectable persons, amount handed over to pujaris' representative after deducting expenses if applicable

anchor.surface_text: We therefore accept the view of the Bombay, Calcutta, Allahabad and Patna High Courts in this matter and hold that it is open in a suit under s. 92 where a scheme is to be settled to provide in the scheme for modifying it as and when necessity arises,
